docs.title: TLDR
docs.text:
# install 
pip install autonomy-dev[all]

# create a repo & a simple webserver agent
adev repo scaffold fun_new_hack && \
cd fun_new_hack && \
adev create author/cool_agent \
    -t eightballer/frontend_agent # type of template to use.
# sync to the local registry.
yes 'third_party' | autonomy packages lock

docs.title: Documentation
docs.text:
For detailed information about using auto_dev, check out our documentation:

  • Installation Guide - Complete setup instructions and environment configuration
  • Usage Guide - Detailed examples and common workflows
  • CLI Reference - Comprehensive command-line interface documentation
  • Deployment Guide - Instructions for local and production deployments

For development setup and contribution guidelines, see the Installation Guide.

docs.title: Local Documentation
docs.text: To run the documentation locally: 1. Follow the documentation setup guide 2. Visit http://127.0.0.1:8000/ in your browser 3. Documentation will auto-reload as you make changes

docs.title: Development
docs.text: For development tools and workflows: - Code Formatting - Learn about code formatting standards - Testing - Running and writing tests - Contributing - Guidelines for contributing - Deployment - Setting up development environments

docs.title: Usage Examples
docs.text:
Check out these guides for common use cases: - Quick Start - Get started quickly - Protocol Scaffolding - Generate protocol components - Contract Integration - Work with smart contracts - Development Tools - Available development tools

# run the agent and verify the endpoint

docs.title: Usage
docs.text:
There are a number of useful command tools available.

  • Dev Tooling: A). linting adev lint B). formatting adev fmt C). dependency management adev deps update

  • Scaffolding: Tooling to auto generate repositories and components.

docs.title: Create
docs.text: • Templated agents for speedy proof of concept and getting started fast.

docs.title: Protocols
docs.text:
We provide tools to generate protocols components from specs.

adev create author/tmp_agent_name -t eightballer/base --force
cd tmp_agent_name
adev scaffold protocol ../specs/protocols/balances.yaml 
aea -s publish --push-missing
...
Starting Auto Dev v0.2.75 ...
Using 32 processes for processing
Setting log level to INFO
Creating agent tmp_agent_name from template eightballer/base
Executing command: ['poetry', 'run', 'autonomy', 'fetch', 'bafybeidohldv57m3jkc33zpgbxukaushmcibmt4ncnsnomd3pvpocxs3ui', '--alias', 'tmp_agent_name']
Command executed successfully.
Agent tmp_agent_name created successfully.
Starting Auto Dev v0.2.75 ...
Using 32 processes for processing
Setting log level to INFO
Read protocol specification: ../specs/protocols/balances.yaml
protolint version 0.50.0(d6a3250)
protolint version 0.50.0(d6a3250)
Updated: /home/eight/Projects/StationsStation/repos/capitalisation_station/tmp_agent_name/protocols/balances/custom_types.py
New protocol scaffolded at /home/eight/Projects/StationsStation/repos/capitalisation_station/tmp_agent_name/protocols/balances

...
# Tests can be run as well;
adev test -p packages/eightballer/protocols/balances
Testing path: `packages/eightballer/protocols/balances/` ⌛
Testing... ━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━   0% -:--:--👌 - packages/eightballer/protocols/balances/
Testing... ━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━ 100% 0:00:02
Testing completed successfully! ✅

docs.title: Contracts
docs.text:
We can scaffold a new contract using the adev scaffold contract command. This will create a new directory with; - open-aea contract component - open-aea contract component class 🎉 - open-aea contract component function generation 🚧 - open-aea contract component test generation 🚧

adev scaffold contract 0xc939df369C0Fc240C975A6dEEEE77d87bCFaC259 beyond_pricer \
      --block-explorer-api-key $BLOCK_EXPLORER_API_KEY \
      --block-explorer-url "https://api-goerli.arbiscan.io"

docs.title: Scaffolding a new DAO
docs.text: The tools within the dao subcommand are used to scaffold a new DAO (Data Access Object) based on an OpenAPI 3 specification. This process automates the creation of DAO classes, dummy data, and test scripts.

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text:
1. An OpenAPI 3 specification file with components/schema models defined.
  2. A component.yaml file in the current directory that references the OpenAPI specification using the api_spec field.

docs.title: Steps to Scaffold a DAO
docs.text:
1. Ensure you have the OpenAPI 3 specification file. You can view its contents using:
cat auto_dev/data/openapi/openapi_specification.yaml
  1. Create or update the component.yaml file to reference the OpenAPI specification using the api_spec field.
api_spec: <path_to_openapi_specification.yaml>
  1. Run the DAO scaffolding command:
adev scaffold dao

The scaffolding process creates the following:

  1. DAO Classes: For each model defined in the OpenAPI specification, a corresponding DAO class is generated.
  2. Dummy Data:
  3. Aggregated dummy data for all models
  4. Individual dummy data instances for testing
  5. Test Script: A test script to validate the generated DAO classes

To identify the persistent schemas, the scaffolder uses the following logic:

  1. It checks whether custom x-persistent field is set to true for a schema. If it is, the schema is identified as a persistent schema.
components:
   schemas:
      User:
         x-persistent: true  # Marking the schema as persistent
         type: object
         properties:
            name:
               type: string
               ...
  1. If no x-persistent tags are found, it then attempts to identify all the schemas in the OpenAPI specification by checking if they are used in any request or response.
  2. If the schema is used in a request and is used in multiple contexts (request or response), it is identified as a persistent schema.

docs.title: Generated File Structure
docs.text:
After running the scaffold command, you'll find the following structure in your project:

generated/
├── dao/
│ ├── <model_name_1>dao.py
│ ├── <model_name_2>dao.py
│ └── ...
├── aggregated_data.json
└── test_dao.py

docs.title: How It Works
docs.text:
The scaffolding process involves several steps:

  1. Loading and validating the OpenAPI specification (checking for required fields, etc.)
  2. Generating DAO classes for each model
  3. Creating dummy data for testing
  4. Generating a test script

For more details on the implementation, refer to: auto_dev/dao/scaffolder.py

docs.title: Customization
docs.text: The generated DAO classes use Jinja2 templates for customization. If you need to modify the structure of the generated classes, you can update the templates located in the auto_dev/data/templates/dao directory.

docs.title: Error Handling
docs.text:
The scaffolding process includes comprehensive error handling to catch issues such as: - Missing or invalid OpenAPI specification - YAML or JSON parsing errors - File I/O errors

If any errors occur during the scaffolding process, detailed error messages will be logged to help with troubleshooting.

docs.title: Next Steps
docs.text:
After scaffolding your DAO:

  1. Review the generated DAO classes in the generated/dao/ directory.
  2. Examine the aggregated_data.json file for the structure of the dummy data.
  3. Run the test_dao.py script to ensure the basic functionality of your DAOs.
  4. Customize the generated classes as needed for your specific use case.

Remember to regenerate the DAOs if you make changes to your OpenAPI specification to keep them in sync.

docs.title: Deployment Guide
docs.text: This guide covers different deployment scenarios for auto_dev projects, from local development to production environments.

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text:
• Python 3.11+ (via pyenv)
  • Poetry for dependency management
  • Git for version control

docs.title: Setup Steps
docs.text:
1. Clone and set up the repository: 

    git clone https://github.com/8ball030/auto_dev.git
cd auto_dev

  2. Install dependencies: 

    pip install -e .[all]

  3. Configure environment variables: 

    export BLOCK_EXPLORER_API_KEY=your_api_key
# Optional: Custom block explorer URL
export BLOCK_EXPLORER_URL="https://api-goerli.arbiscan.io"

  4. Set up pre-commit hooks: 

    pre-commit install

docs.title: Development Server
docs.text:
For local development and testing:

  1. Run formatting: 

    poetry run adev fmt -p .

  2. Run linting: 

    poetry run adev lint -p .

  3. Run tests: 

    poetry run adev test -p tests

docs.title: System Requirements
docs.text:
• Linux-based OS (Ubuntu 20.04+ recommended)
  • Python 3.11+
  • Sufficient disk space for dependencies
  • Network access for API calls

docs.title: Installation Steps
docs.text:
1. Create a dedicated user (optional but recommended): 

    sudo useradd -m -s /bin/bash autodev
sudo su - autodev

  2. Install system dependencies: 

    sudo apt-get update
sudo apt-get install -y python3-pip python3-venv git

  3. Install auto_dev: 

    pip install autonomy-dev[all]

  4. Set up environment variables (add to ~/.bashrc): 

    echo 'export BLOCK_EXPLORER_API_KEY="your_api_key"' >> ~/.bashrc
echo 'export BLOCK_EXPLORER_URL="your_explorer_url"' >> ~/.bashrc
source ~/.bashrc

docs.title: Service Configuration
docs.text:
For running auto_dev components as services:

  1. Create a systemd service file: 

    [Unit]
Description=Auto Dev Service
After=network.target

[Service]
Type=simple
User=autodev
Environment=BLOCK_EXPLORER_API_KEY=your_api_key
Environment=BLOCK_EXPLORER_URL=your_explorer_url
WorkingDirectory=/home/autodev/auto_dev
ExecStart=/usr/local/bin/adev your_command
Restart=always

[Install]
WantedBy=multi-user.target

  2. Enable and start the service: 

    sudo systemctl enable autodev
sudo systemctl start autodev

docs.title: Monitoring
docs.text:
Monitor your deployment using: 

sudo systemctl status autodev
journalctl -u autodev -f

docs.title: Docker Deployment (Optional)
docs.text:
While auto_dev doesn't currently provide official Docker images, you can containerize your auto_dev projects using this example configuration:

  1. Create a Dockerfile: 

    FROM python:3.11-slim

# Install system dependencies
RUN apt-get update && apt-get install -y \
    git \
    && rm -rf /var/lib/apt/lists/*

# Install auto_dev
RUN pip install autonomy-dev[all]

# Set working directory
WORKDIR /app

# Copy your project files
COPY . .

# Set environment variables
ENV BLOCK_EXPLORER_API_KEY=your_api_key
ENV BLOCK_EXPLORER_URL=your_explorer_url

# Run your command
CMD ["adev", "your_command"]

  2. Build and run: 

    docker build -t auto_dev .
docker run -e BLOCK_EXPLORER_API_KEY=your_key auto_dev

docs.title: Docker Compose
docs.text:
For more complex setups, use docker-compose:

version: '3'
services:
  auto_dev:
    build: .
    environment:
      - BLOCK_EXPLORER_API_KEY=${BLOCK_EXPLORER_API_KEY}
      - BLOCK_EXPLORER_URL=${BLOCK_EXPLORER_URL}
    volumes:
      - .:/app

docs.title: Common Issues
docs.text:
1. Missing Dependencies 

    pip install -e .[all]  # Reinstall with all optional dependencies

  2. Environment Variables 

    # Verify environment variables
echo $BLOCK_EXPLORER_API_KEY
echo $BLOCK_EXPLORER_URL

  3. Service Issues 

    # Check service logs
journalctl -u autodev -n 100

docs.title: Getting Help
docs.text:
• Check the installation guide for setup issues
  • Review the usage guide for command usage
  • Submit issues on GitHub

docs.title: Scaffolding a new FSM agent.
docs.text:
It can be difficult to scaffold an initial agent to begin development of the fsm.

The tools within the fsm subcommand are used to scaffold a new agent.

We start with a simple fsm;

cat auto_dev/data/fsm/fsm_specification.yaml

Output: 

alphabet_in:
- DONE
- NO_MAJORITY
- TIMEOUT
default_start_state: FirstRound
final_states:
- ErrorRound
- FinalRound
label: DummyAbciApp
start_states:
- FirstRound
states:
- FirstRound
- FinalRound
- ErrorRound
transition_func:
  (FirstRound, DONE): FinalRound
  (FirstRound, NO_MAJORITY): ErrorRound
  (FirstRound, TIMEOUT): ErrorRound

We can then convert this to a mermaid diagram using the adev tool.

adev fsm from-file auto_dev/data/fsm/fsm_specification.yaml --output mermaid DemoAbciApp

Output: 

graph TD
  FirstRound
  FirstRound
  FinalRound
  ErrorRound
  FirstRound -->|DONE| FinalRound
  FirstRound -->|NO_MAJORITY| ErrorRound
  FirstRound -->|TIMEOUT| ErrorRound
which can be rendered as a mermaid diagram as so;

graph TD
  FirstRound
  FirstRound
  FinalRound
  ErrorRound
  FirstRound -->|DONE| FinalRound
  FirstRound -->|NO_MAJORITY| ErrorRound
  FirstRound -->|TIMEOUT| ErrorRound

We now scaffold the agent.

adev create -t eightballer/base author/new_agent
We now have a new agent.

cd new_agent

This creates a new agent without any real skills.

Once we have a new agent, we can first scaffold the skill using the CORE autonomy libraries.

This reduces the amount of code we need to write to get a skill up and means that we have no need to write any code to re-implement the wheel.

adev scaffold fsm --spec ../auto_dev/data/fsm/fsm_specification.yaml

We now have an agent with a new skill, HOWEVER The agent will not run.

One of the main reasons for this is that the agent is not configured to use the aea_ledger_ethereum package.

Additionally,

A number of connections need to be updated such that when deploying a service, the environment variables are set correctly.

docs.title: setup the agent
docs.text:
aea generate-key ethereum

aea add-key ethereum


echo run the agent with `aea run`

docs.title: Quick Install
docs.text:
For users who just want to use auto_dev, install via pip:

$ pip install autonomy-dev[all]

This installs the latest stable release with all optional dependencies.

docs.title: Quick Start Example
docs.text:
# Create a repo & a simple webserver agent
adev repo scaffold fun_new_hack && \
cd fun_new_hack && \
adev create author/cool_agent \
    -t eightballer/frontend_agent # type of template to use

# Sync to the local registry
yes 'third_party' | autonomy packages lock

docs.title: Development Setup
docs.text:
For developers who want to contribute or modify the code:

  1. Set up Python environment (Python 3.11+ recommended): 

    # Install pyenv if needed
curl https://pyenv.run | bash

# Install Python 3.11
pyenv install 3.11
pyenv global 3.11

  2. Clone the repository: 

    git clone https://github.com/8ball030/auto_dev.git
cd auto_dev

  3. Install development dependencies: 

    pip install -e .[all]

  4. Set up pre-commit hooks: 

    pre-commit install

docs.title: Repository Structure
docs.text: Key directories: - auto_dev/: Core functionality - commands/: CLI tools implementation - contracts/: Contract-related functionality - dao/: Data Access Object generation - handlers/: Message handling components - protocols/: Protocol scaffolding - behaviours/: Agent behavior definitions - fsm/: Finite State Machine management - data/: Templates and configuration files

docs.title: Development Tools
docs.text:
The repository uses several development tools:

  1. Poetry for dependency management
  2. pre-commit for code quality checks
  3. pytest for testing (current coverage: ~35%)
  4. mkdocs for documentation

docs.title: Running Documentation Locally
docs.text:
To run and develop the documentation locally:

  1. Install documentation dependencies: 

    pip install mkdocs-material mkdocs-include-markdown-plugin mkdocstrings[python] mkdocs-autorefs

  2. Serve documentation locally: 

    mkdocs serve
    This will start a development server at http://127.0.0.1:8000/

  3. Build documentation (optional): 

    mkdocs build
    This generates static files in the site/ directory

The documentation will auto-reload when you make changes to the markdown files.

docs.title: Environment Variables
docs.text:
Some features require environment variables:

  1. Block Explorer Integration: 
    export BLOCK_EXPLORER_API_KEY=your_api_key
# Optional: Custom block explorer URL
export BLOCK_EXPLORER_URL="https://api-goerli.arbiscan.io"

docs.title: Development Commands
docs.text:
# Format code
poetry run adev -n 0 fmt -p . -co

# Lint code
poetry run adev -v -n 0 lint -p . -co

# Run tests
poetry run adev -v test -p tests

# Test specific components
adev test -p packages/eightballer/protocols/balances

# Release process
git checkout main
git pull
adev release

docs.title: Troubleshooting
docs.text:
Common issues and solutions:

  1. Missing dependencies: 

    pip install -e .[all]  # Reinstall with all optional dependencies

  2. Pre-commit hook failures: 

    pre-commit run --all-files  # Run all checks manually

  3. Python version conflicts: 

    pyenv install 3.11  # Install correct Python version
pyenv local 3.11    # Set local Python version

docs.title: Scaffolding a new API Handler agent.
docs.text:
The tools within the handler subcommand are used to scaffold a new agent.

We start with a simple openapi;

cat auto_dev/data/openapi/openapi_specification.yaml

We now scaffold the agent and cd in.

aea create new_agent && cd new_agent

This creates a new agent without any real skills.

Once we have a new agent, we can now use the cli to scaffold the skill using the CORE autonomy libraries and the OpenAPI specification.

This reduces the amount of code we need to write to get a skill up and means that we have no need to write any code to re-implement the wheel.

docs.title: Scaffolding a new skill
docs.text:
Use the --new-skill flag to scaffold a new skill.

adev scaffold handler ../auto_dev/data/openapi/openapi_specification.yaml --output my_api_skill --new-skill

The skill will be created in the skills directory. The user will be prompted whether to rename MyModel.py to strategy.py, and whether to remove the dialogues.py file. THe scaffolding step will also install the http protocol, and fingerprint the skill. At the completion, the user can now run the agent.

aea run

docs.title: Augmenting with an OpenAPI Handler
docs.text: The tools within the openapi subcommand are used to augment a customs component with a new handler based on an OpenAPI 3 specification. This process automates the creation of endpoints methods.

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text:
1. An OpenAPI 3 specification file with paths, operationIds, and schemas defined.
  2. A component.yaml file in the current directory that references the OpenAPI specification using the api_spec field.
  3. DAOs for each schema in the OpenAPI specification (see dao docs for how to scaffold these).

docs.title: Steps to Augment a Handler
docs.text:
1. Ensure you have the OpenAPI 3 specification file. You can view its contents using:
cat auto_dev/data/openapi/openapi_specification.yaml
  1. Create or update the component.yaml file to reference the OpenAPI specification using the api_spec field.
api_spec: <path_to_openapi_specification.yaml>
  1. Run the Handler augmenting command:
adev augment customs openapi3

The augmenting process creates the following:

  1. Handler methods: For each path defined in the OpenAPI specification, a corresponding handler method is generated, along with a general handler and resolver method.
  2. Dialogues.py: A boilerplate dialogues file is generated.

docs.title: How It Works
docs.text:
The augmentation process involves several steps:

  1. Loading and validating the OpenAPI specification
  2. Generating Handler methods for each path

For more details on the implementation, refer to: auto_dev/handler/scaffolder.py

docs.title: Customization
docs.text: The generated Handler methods use Jinja2 templates for customization. If you need to modify the structure of the generated classes, you can update the templates located in the JINJA_TEMPLATE_FOLDER.

docs.title: Next Steps
docs.text:
After augmenting your handler:

  • Review the generated handler methods in the handlers.py file.

Remember to regenerate the Handlers if you make changes to your OpenAPI specification to keep them in sync.

docs.title: Quick Start Guide
docs.text: This guide will help you get started with auto_dev quickly.

docs.title: Basic Usage
docs.text:
1. Create a new agent: 

    adev create -t eightballer/frontend_agent my_author/my_agent

  2. Scaffold components: 

    # Add a contract
adev scaffold contract --from-abi contract.abi --name MyContract

# Add an FSM
adev scaffold fsm --spec fsm_spec.yaml

  3. Format and lint code: 

    # Format code
adev fmt -p .

# Lint code
adev lint -p .

  4. Run tests: 

    adev test -p tests

docs.title: Creating a New Agent
docs.text:
1. Choose a template: 

    # List available templates
adev create --help

# Create from template
adev create -t eightballer/frontend_agent my_author/my_agent

  2. Scaffold Protocol Components: 

    # Create a temporary agent
adev create author/tmp_agent_name -t eightballer/base --force
cd tmp_agent_name

# Generate protocol from spec
adev scaffold protocol ../specs/protocols/balances.yaml

# Publish to registry
aea -s publish --push-missing

  3. Scaffold Contract Components: 

    # Generate contract from address
adev scaffold contract 0xc939df369C0Fc240C975A6dEEEE77d87bCFaC259 contract_name \
      --block-explorer-api-key $BLOCK_EXPLORER_API_KEY \
      --block-explorer-url "https://api-goerli.arbiscan.io"

This creates: - Open-AEA contract component class - Contract component function generation (in progress) - Contract component test generation (in progress)

docs.title: Development Workflow
docs.text:
1. Format code before committing: 

    adev fmt -p . --changed-only

  2. Run linting: 

    adev lint -p . --changed-only

  3. Run tests: 

    adev test -p tests --coverage-report

docs.title: Overriding Default Templates
docs.text:
# List available templates
adev create --help

# Create custom template
adev create my_author/custom_agent -t eightballer/base --force

# Override specific components
adev create my_author/custom_agent \
    -t eightballer/frontend_agent \
    --override-protocol my_protocol \
    --override-connection my_connection

docs.title: Multiple Protocol Generation
docs.text:
# Generate multiple protocols from specs
for spec in specs/protocols/*.yaml; do
    adev scaffold protocol "$spec"
done

# Publish all to registry
aea -s publish --push-missing

docs.title: Custom Contract Integration
docs.text:
# Generate contract with custom settings
adev scaffold contract 0xAddress contract_name \
    --block-explorer-api-key $BLOCK_EXPLORER_API_KEY \
    --block-explorer-url "https://api-goerli.arbiscan.io" \
    --custom-abi path/to/abi.json \
    --implementation-class MyCustomContract

# Generate multiple contracts
for addr in $CONTRACT_ADDRESSES; do
    adev scaffold contract "$addr" "${addr}_contract" \
        --block-explorer-api-key $BLOCK_EXPLORER_API_KEY
done

docs.title: Advanced FSM Workflows
docs.text:
# Generate FSM from complex spec
adev scaffold fsm \
    --spec complex_fsm.yaml \
    --custom-states custom_states.py \
    --transitions transitions.yaml

# Chain multiple FSMs
adev scaffold fsm-chain \
    --specs "fsm1.yaml,fsm2.yaml,fsm3.yaml" \
    --output chained_fsm.yaml

docs.title: Development Best Practices
docs.text:
1. Code Quality 

    # Format only changed files
adev fmt -p . --changed-only

# Run specific linting checks
adev lint -p . --select E,W,F

# Run tests with coverage
adev test -p tests --coverage-report

  2. Dependency Management 

    # Update specific dependencies
adev deps update -p . --packages "package1,package2"

# Check for outdated dependencies
adev deps check -p .

# Update all dependencies
adev deps update -p . --all

  3. Release Process 

    # Prepare release
git checkout main
git pull
adev release --dry-run  # Check what would be released

# Perform release
adev release

docs.title: Next Steps
docs.text:
• Check the CLI Reference for detailed command documentation
  • Explore FSM documentation for state machine development
  • Read OpenAPI guide for API integration
  • Review Deployment Guide for production setup

docs.title: API Reference Overview
docs.text: This section provides detailed information about the auto_dev API. Use the navigation menu to explore specific modules and components.

docs.title: Main Modules
docs.text:
• auto_dev: Core functionality
  • Commands: CLI commands
  • Connections: Network connections
  • Contracts: Smart contract interactions
  • FSM: Finite State Machine implementation
  • Handler: Request handling
  • Protocols: Communication protocols
  • Utils: Utility functions
  • Constants: Constant values used across the project

docs.title: get_py_type_and_args(arg, arg_type, type_map)
docs.text: Get the python type and arguments from a protobuf type.

docs.title: check_dependencies
docs.text:
This script checks that the pipfile of the repository meets the requirements.

In particular: - Avoid the usage of "*"

It is assumed the script is run from the repository root.

docs.title: main(check=False, packages_dir=None, pipfile_path=None, pyproject_path=None)
docs.text: Check dependencies across packages, tox.ini, pyproject.toml and setup.py

docs.title: cli
docs.text: Simple cli to allow users to perform the following actions against an autonomy repo.

docs.title: cli_executor
docs.text: Simple command execution class. It is used to execute commands in a subprocess and return the output. It is also used to check if a command was successful or not. It is used by the lint and test functions.

docs.title: customs(ctx, component_type, auto_confirm)
docs.text: Augment a customs component with OpenAPI3 handlers.

docs.title: create
docs.text: This module contains the logic for the fmt command.

docs.title: create(ctx, public_id, template, force, publish, clean_up)
docs.text:
Create a new agent from a template.

:flag template: the template to use.

example usage: adev create -t eightballer/frontend_agent new_author/new_agent

Parameters:

Name Type Description Default public_id str

the public_id of the agent in the open-autonmy format i.e. author/agent

required

docs.title: publish_agent(public_id, verbose)
docs.text:
Publish an agent.

Parameters:

Name Type Description Default public_id PublicId

the public_id of the agent.

required

docs.title: update_author(public_id)
docs.text: Update the author in the recently created agent

docs.title: deps
docs.text:
reads in 2 github repos.

One is the parent repo, the other is the child repo.

The child repo is dependent on the parent repo.

When there is a change in the parent repo, we want to update the child repo.

The dependencies are defined in a file called packages/packages.json

this is structures as follows:

{ "dev": { "aea_dep1": "ipfshash", "aea_dep2": "ipfshash", }, "third_party": { "aea_dep3": "ipfshash", "aea_dep4": "ipfshash", }, }

The ipfshash is the hash of the package.

We want to be able to update the hash of the package.

docs.title: DEFAULT_ADEV_CONFIG_FILE = Path('adev_config.yaml') module-attribute
docs.text:
• name: open-autonomy version: 0.15.2 location: remote url: https://api.github.com/repos/valory-xyz/open-autonomy
  • name: open-aea version: 1.55.0 location: remote url: https://api.github.com/repos/valory-xyz/open-aea

poetry_dependencies: - name: autonomy-dev version: 0.2.73 location: remote url: https://api.github.com/repos/8ball030/auto_dev extras: - all - name: open-autonomy version: 0.15.2 location: remote url: https://api.github.com/repos/valory-xyz/open-autonomy - name: open-aea version: 1.55.0 location: remote url: https://api.github.com/repos/valory-xyz/open-aea plugins: - open-aea-ledger-ethereum - open-aea-ledger-solana - open-aea-ledger-cosmos - open-aea-cli-ipfs

docs.title: deps(ctx)
docs.text: Commands for managing dependencies. - update: Update both the packages.json from the parent repo and the packages in the child repo. - generate_gitignore: Generate the gitignore file from the packages.json file.

docs.title: from_key_to_path(key)
docs.text: We get the path from the key string some examples of the keys are; agent/eightballer/custom_balance_poller/0.1.0 where the folder to be removed is; packages/eightballer/agents/custom_balance_poller.

docs.title: generate_gitignore(ctx)
docs.text: We generate the gitignore file from the packages.json file Example usage: adev deps generate_gitignore.

docs.title: update(ctx, parent_repo, child_repo, location=DependencyLocation.LOCAL, auto_confirm=False)
docs.text: We update aea packages.json dependencies from a parent repo. Example usage: adev deps update -p /path/to/parent/repo -c /path/to/child/repo.

docs.title: verify(ctx, auto_approve=False)

Verify the packages.json file.

Example usage: adev deps verify

docs.title: metadata

docs.title: check_component_status(component_id)

NOTES: if the component is NOT present in the mapping.txt file, it is NOT minted. if the component is present in the we always return the token_id, even if it is not minted.

docs.title: CLI Commands Reference
docs.text: This page provides a comprehensive reference for all available CLI commands in auto_dev.

docs.title: create
docs.text:
Create a new agent from a template.

adev create -t <template> <author/agent_name>

Options: - -t, --template: Template to use (required) - -f, --force: Force overwrite of existing agent - -p, --publish: Publish agent to local registry (default: true) - -c, --clean-up: Clean up agent after creation (default: true)

Example: 

adev create -t eightballer/frontend_agent new_author/new_agent

docs.title: scaffold contract
docs.text:
adev scaffold contract [--address ADDRESS] [--from-file FILE] [--from-abi FILE] [name]

Options: - --address: Contract address (default: null address) - --from-file: File containing addresses and names - --from-abi: ABI file to scaffold from - --read-functions: Comma-separated list of read functions - --write-functions: Comma-separated list of write functions - --block-explorer-url: Block explorer API URL (default: https://api.etherscan.io/api) - --block-explorer-api-key: Block explorer API key

Example: 

# Scaffold from ABI file
adev scaffold contract --from-abi contract.abi --name MyContract

# Scaffold from block explorer
adev scaffold contract --address 0x123... --name MyContract --block-explorer-api-key KEY

docs.title: scaffold fsm
docs.text:
Scaffold a Finite State Machine (FSM) for your agent.

adev scaffold fsm [--spec SPEC_FILE]

Options: - --spec: FSM specification YAML file

Example: 

adev scaffold fsm --spec fsm_specification.yaml

docs.title: scaffold protocol
docs.text:
Generate a new protocol package.

adev scaffold protocol PROTOCOL_SPEC_PATH [--l LANGUAGE]

Options: - --l: Language for protocol package (default: python, choices: python, golang)

Example: 

adev scaffold protocol protocol_specification.yaml --l python

docs.title: scaffold connection
docs.text:
Create a new connection for a protocol.

adev scaffold connection NAME --protocol PROTOCOL_ID

Options: - --protocol: PublicId of the protocol (required)

Example: 

adev scaffold connection my_connection --protocol author/protocol:0.1.0

docs.title: scaffold handler
docs.text:
Generate an AEA handler from an OpenAPI 3 specification.

adev scaffold handler SPEC_FILE PUBLIC_ID [--new-skill] [--auto-confirm]

Options: - --new-skill: Create a new skill - --auto-confirm: Auto confirm all actions

Example: 

adev scaffold handler api_spec.yaml author/skill:0.1.0 --new-skill

docs.title: scaffold behaviour
docs.text:
Generate a behaviour component.

adev scaffold behaviour SPEC_FILE [--behaviour-type TYPE] [--auto-confirm]

Options: - --behaviour-type: Type of behaviour (metrics, simple_fsm) - --auto-confirm: Auto confirm all actions - --target-speech-acts: Comma-separated list of speech acts to scaffold

Example: 

adev scaffold behaviour spec.yaml --behaviour-type metrics

docs.title: scaffold dialogues
docs.text:
Generate dialogue components.

adev scaffold dialogues SPEC_FILE [--dialogue-type TYPE] [--auto-confirm]

Options: - --dialogue-type: Type of dialogue (simple) - --auto-confirm: Auto confirm all actions - --target-speech-acts: Comma-separated list of speech acts to scaffold

Example: 

adev scaffold dialogues spec.yaml --dialogue-type simple

docs.title: scaffold tests
docs.text:
Generate test files.

adev scaffold tests SPEC_FILE

Example: 

adev scaffold tests test_specification.yaml

docs.title: scaffold dao
docs.text:
Generate Data Access Object (DAO) from OpenAPI specification.

adev scaffold dao SPEC_FILE

Example: 

adev scaffold dao openapi_spec.yaml

docs.title: deps
docs.text:
Manage dependencies between repositories.

adev deps update -p PARENT_REPO -c CHILD_REPO [--auto-confirm]

Options: - -p, --parent-repo: Parent repository path - -c, --child-repo: Child repository path - --auto-confirm: Auto confirm changes

docs.title: fmt
docs.text:
Format code according to project standards.

adev fmt -p PATH [--changed-only]

Options: - -p, --path: Path to code to format - --changed-only: Only format changed files

docs.title: lint
docs.text:
Lint code according to project standards.

adev lint -p PATH [--changed-only]

Options: - -p, --path: Path to code to lint - --changed-only: Only lint changed files

docs.title: test
docs.text:
Run project tests.

adev test -p TEST_PATH [--watch] [--coverage-report]

Options: - -p, --path: Path to directory to test. If not provided, will test all packages - -w, --watch: Watch files for changes - -c, --coverage-report: Run coverage report (default: true)

Example: 

# Test specific package with coverage
adev test -p packages/eightballer/protocols/balances

# Test all packages with file watching
adev test --watch

docs.title: release
docs.text:
Manage project releases by automatically bumping versions and creating tags.

adev release [--dep-path PATH] [--verbose]

Options: - -p, --dep-path: Path to dependency file (default: pyproject.toml) - --verbose: Enable verbose output

The release command will: 1. Check if the repository is clean 2. Increment the version number 3. Create a new tag 4. Push changes to GitHub 5. Trigger GitHub Actions for PyPI publishing

docs.title: repo
docs.text:
Scaffold new repositories.

adev repo scaffold [--type-of-repo TYPE] [--force] [--auto-approve] [--install/--no-install] [--initial-commit/--no-commit]

Options: - --type-of-repo: Type of repo to scaffold - --force: Force overwrite existing repo - --auto-approve: Auto approve all prompts - --install/--no-install: Control dependency installation - --initial-commit/--no-commit: Control initial commit

docs.title: improve
docs.text:
Improve repository structure and configuration.

adev improve --path PATH [--type-of-repo TYPE] [--author AUTHOR] [--name NAME] [--yes]

Options: - --path: Path to repo - --type-of-repo: Type of repo - --author: Author name - --name: Repository name - --yes: Auto answer yes to all questions

docs.title: augment logging
docs.text:
Add logging handlers to your AEA configuration.

adev augment logging [HANDLERS...]

Available handlers: - console: Rich console logging handler - http: HTTP logging handler for remote logging - logfile: File-based logging handler

Example: 

# Add console and file logging
adev augment logging console logfile

# Add all available handlers
adev augment logging all

docs.title: augment connection
docs.text:
Add connections to your AEA configuration.

adev augment connection [CONNECTIONS...]

Available connections: - ledger: Ethereum ledger connection - abci: ABCI connection for Tendermint - ipfs: IPFS connection - http_client: HTTP client connection - http_server: HTTP server connection - websocket_server: WebSocket server connection - prometheus: Prometheus metrics connection

Example: 

# Add ledger and IPFS connections
adev augment connection ledger ipfs

# Add all available connections
adev augment connection all

docs.title: augment customs
docs.text:
Augment customs components with OpenAPI handlers.

adev augment customs openapi3 [--auto-confirm]

Options: - --auto-confirm: Auto confirm the augmentation

docs.title: Environment Setup
docs.text:
To install auto_dev:

pip install autonomy-dev[all]

For development setup: 1. Clone the repository 2. Install dependencies: pip install -e .[all] 3. Install pre-commit hooks: pre-commit install
